key_insight: GateFusion bridges strong pretrained audio and visual encoders with a Hierarchical Gated Fusion Decoder (HiGat) to capture fine-grained, multi-level cross-modal interactions that late fusion misses.
problem_solved: Active Speaker Detection (ASD) models that fuse modalities late often miss detailed audioâ€“visual correlations, reducing robustness in unconstrained, noisy, or multi-speaker scenarios.
method: Use strong pretrained unimodal encoders for audio and visual streams to extract rich modality-specific features.
Introduce a Hierarchical Gated Fusion Decoder (HiGat) that performs gated cross-modal interactions at multiple representation levels to selectively combine complementary cues.
Predict per-frame active speaker labels using the fused hierarchical representation, improving alignment between speaking voice and visible mouth motion.
impact: Provides a practical multimodal fusion strategy that boosts robustness and fine-grained alignment for ASD, and can be plugged into systems that already use pretrained encoders to improve performance in real-world videos.
visual_elements: Architecture diagram: two pretrained encoders (audio, visual) feeding into a hierarchical stack of gated fusion blocks (HiGat) with arrows showing gated information flow.
Temporal frame sequence: video frames with overlaid speaker labels and audio waveform to illustrate per-frame detection.
Gate activation heatmaps: side-by-side visualizations showing where gates attend to audio vs visual cues across layers and time.
Performance comparison chart: bar or line chart comparing GateFusion vs late-fusion baselines on robustness metrics (e.g., noisy, overlapping speech).
paper_title: GateFusion: Hierarchical Gated Cross-Modal Fusion for Active Speaker Detection
paper_authors: Yu Wang, Juhyung Ha, Frangil M. Ramirez, Yuchen Wang, David J. Crandall
